elements.content: Three new crystallographically characterized compounds were prepared in high yield from reactions between [Cp2Co]­PF6 (Cp = cyclopentadiene) and lithium salts of the radical anion of 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQF4 1–) or the dianionic TCNQF4 2–. The two [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 compounds (1 and 2) with 1:1 stoichiometry were found to be polymorphic, α and β. Remarkably, the syntheses only differed by the presence of a small amount of neutral TCNQF4 in the case of polymorph β (2). The role of the TCNQF4 has been rationalized on the basis of a transient intermediate, postulated as [Cp2Co]­(TCNQF4)2. Compound 3 contains TCNQF4 2– and crystallized as [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4). This material highlights a novel coordination mode for the Li+ cation that participated in the formation of a metal–organic framework accommodating the [Cp2Co]+ cation. All complexes were comprehensively characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV–vis spectroscopy, and electrochemistry. Polymorph β (2) has a conductivity of 5.8 × 10–4 S cm–1, which lies well within the semiconductor range. Previous work in this area employed redox chemistry based on the reaction of cobaltocene or ferrocene with neutral TCNQ. The introduction of metathesis reactions enhances the synthetic flexibility enabling a systematic approach to new materials.

The role of the TCNQF4 has been rationalized on the basis of a transient intermediate, postulated as [Cp2Co](TCNQF4)2. Compound 3 contains TCNQF4 2- and crystallized as [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4). The introduction of metathesis reactions enhances the synthetic flexibility enabling a systematic approach to new materials.

elements.content: Reaction of [Cp2Co]­PF6 with either LiTCNQF4 or Li2TCNQF4 affords two [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 polymorphs with 1:1 stoichiometry or [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4). All compounds gave single crystals suitable for X-ray determination and were characterized using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV−vis spectroscopy, and electrochemistry. Use of metathesis reactions enhanced the synthetic flexibility allowing a systematic approach to new materials to be obtained.

elements.content: 7,7,8,8-Tetracynaoquinodimethane (TCNQ) is an excellent electron acceptor with a high electron affinity of ∼2.8 eV. Reduced forms of TCNQ have been used for the preparation of a wide range of organic semiconductors, or materials with interesting magnetic and electronic properties. The tetrafluorinated derivative TCNQF4 has an even higher electron affinity of 5.2 eV due to the presence of fluorine. As a consequence, the range of applications using TCNQF-based materials can be extended.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

7,7,8,8-Tetracynaoquinodimethane (TCNQ) is an excellent electron acceptor with a high electron affinity of ~2.8 eV. Reduced forms of TCNQ have been used for the preparation of a wide range of organic semiconductors, or materials with interesting magnetic and electronic properties. The tetrafluorinated derivative TCNQF4 has an even higher electron affinity of 5.2 eV due to the presence of fluorine. As a consequence, the range of applications using TCNQF-based materials can be extended.

elements.content: TCNQ and TCNQF4 can both be reduced to form the radical monoanion TCNQ­(F)1– or the aromatic dianion TCNQ­(F)2–. Additionally, anions containing formally fractionally reduced TCNQ­(F)0<n<1– (n = average charge), e.g., (Pr4N)­(TCNQ)2, (Bu4N)2­(TCNQ)5, as well as mixtures of TCNQ­(F) oxidation states, such as [(Me5Cp)2Fe]­(TCNQ)2 and [Cp2Fe]2­(TCNQ)3 are known. However, TCNQ2– is extremely sensitive to oxidation, which is reflected in a paucity of stable dianionic compounds of this moiety. The presence of the four electron withdrawing fluorines on TCNQF4 shifts the reversible potentials of the TCNQF4 0/1– and TCNQF4 1–/2– processes to considerably more positive values. Thus, TCNQF4 2– is far less sensitive to oxidation than TCNQ2–, thereby giving rise to increased stability of TCNQF4 2–-based materials. The combination of factors surveyed suggests that stoichiometric and nonstoichiometric ratios of cations/anions could be used to create a systematic series of materials based on TCNQ­(F)1–, TCNQ­(F)2–, or fractionally reduced TCNQ­(F)0<n<1–.
elements.clean_text: TCNQ and TCNQF4 can both be reduced to form the radical monoanion TCNQ(F)1- or the aromatic dianion TCNQ(F)2-. Additionally, anions containing formally fractionally reduced TCNQ(F)0<n<1- (n = average charge), e.g., (Pr4N)(TCNQ)2, (Bu4N)2(TCNQ)5, as well as mixtures of TCNQ(F) oxidation states, such as [(Me5Cp)2Fe](TCNQ)2  and [Cp2Fe]2(TCNQ)3  are known. However, TCNQ2- is extremely sensitive to oxidation, which is reflected in a paucity of stable dianionic compounds of this moiety. The presence of the four electron withdrawing fluorines on TCNQF4 shifts the reversible potentials of the TCNQF4 0/1- and TCNQF4 1-/2- processes to considerably more positive values. Thus, TCNQF4 2- is far less sensitive to oxidation than TCNQ2-, thereby giving rise to increased stability of TCNQF4 2--based materials. The combination of factors surveyed suggests that stoichiometric and nonstoichiometric ratios of cations/anions could be used to create a systematic series of materials based on TCNQ(F)1-, TCNQ(F)2-, or fractionally reduced TCNQ(F)0<n<1-.

elements.content: Here we report the synthesis of two new materials derived from the reaction of cobaltocenium hexafluorophosphate, [(C5H5)2Co]­PF6, (or [Cp2Co]­PF6) with a stoichiometric 1:1 ratio of lithium salts of TCNQF4 (either LiTCNQF4 or Li2TCNQF4). One new material was also derived from nonstoichiometric mixtures of both TCNQF4 and LiTCNQF4 with [Cp2Co]­PF6. All three materials have been comprehensively characterized. Significantly, reactions using a stoichiometric ratio of LiTCNQF4 gave [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4, 1, and those containing variable amounts of neutral TCNQF4 gave 2, referred to as polymorphs α and β, but with very different properties. A rationalization of the impact of using mixtures of TCNQF4 0 and TCNQF4 1– in the synthesis rather than a stoichiometric amount of TCNQF4 1– is provided. Use of a stoichiometric amount Li2TCNQF4 gave [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) (3), incorporating both Li+ and [Cp2Co]+ cations, with the TCNQF4 2– counter dianion. Single crystals of new materials 1–3 were obtained, thus enabling their characterization by X-ray crystallography. Calculated powder diffraction patterns of the two polymorphs also are distinctly different. Further characterization was achieved using vibrational and UV–vis spectroscopy, electrical conductivity, and solution phase electrochemistry. As well as being structurally distinct, the two polymorphs of [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 were found to be strikingly different in conductivity. Our new synthetic approach uses metathesis, whereas previously, Miller et al. used redox chemistry to synthesize TCNQ compounds by reaction of neutral [(Me5Cp)2Co] with neutral TCNQ­(F4/I2). Importantly, our new approach allows us to control the ratio of [Cp2Co]+ to TCNQF4 0, TCNQF4 1–, and TCNQF4 2–. In addition, the use of Li+ salts provides an opportunity to synthesize mixed cation derivatives of TCNQF4 2–.

elements.content: Bis­(cyclopentadienyl) cobalt­(II) hexafluorophosphate ([Cp2Co]­PF6), ferrocene (Fc), silver nitrate, and lithium iodide (LiI) were used as received from Aldrich. 2,3,5,6-Tetrafluoro-7,7′,8,8′-tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQF4, Beijing Health Science & Technology) was recrystallized from acetonitrile prior to use. Methanol (CH3OH), acetonitrile (CH3CN), and diethyl ether were purchased from Aldrich and were dried before use. Tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (Bu4NPF6) was purchased from GFS and recrystallized twice from ethanol. All aqueous solutions were prepared from water (resistivity of 18.2 MΩ·cm) purified by an Arium 611 system (Sartorius). LiTCNQF4 and Li2TCNQF4 were synthesized by literature procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals

Bis(cyclopentadienyl) cobalt(II) hexafluorophosphate ([Cp2Co]PF6), ferrocene (Fc), silver nitrate, and lithium iodide (LiI) were used as received from Aldrich. 2,3,5,6-Tetrafluoro-7,7',8,8'-tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQF4, Beijing Health Science & Technology) was recrystallized from acetonitrile prior to use. Methanol (CH3OH), acetonitrile (CH3CN), and diethyl ether were purchased from Aldrich and were dried before use. Tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (Bu4NPF6) was purchased from GFS and recrystallized twice from ethanol. All aqueous solutions were prepared from water (resistivity of 18.2 MΩ⋅cm) purified by an Arium 611 system (Sartorius). LiTCNQF4 and Li2TCNQF4 were synthesized by literature procedures.

elements.content: A CH3CN (5 mL) solution of [Cp2Co]­PF6 (33.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added to a CH3OH (6 mL) solution of LiTCNQF4 (28.3 mg, 0.1 mmol). The resultant mixture was stirred for 1 h under N2 and filtered to remove the precipitate. The filtrate was diffused with diethyl ether, yielding purple-blue single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis (38 mg, 82%, based on LiTCNQF4). FTIR (ν/cm–1): 3103 (w), 2191 (s), 2179 (s), 2166 (m), 1632 (m), 1535 (m), 1496 (m), 1414 (w), 1382 (s), 1347 (m), 1336 (m), 1261 (w), 1197 (m), 1139 (m), 1010 (w), 966 (s), 871 (m), 786 (m), 715 (w). UV–vis (CH3CN): λmax; 262, 412, 753 (nm). Elemental analysis: for [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4, C22H10N4F4Co, 465.27, Calcd (%): C: 56.79%, H: 2.17%, N: 12.04%. Found: C: 56.63%, H: 2.26%; N: 12.18%.

Synthesis of 2, [Cp2Co]TCNQF4, Polymorph β

In an endeavor to rationally prepare [Cp2Co]+ materials that contain TCNQF4 0 < n <1-, the synthesis of 1 was repeated in the presence of 2.5%, 5%, and 10% neutral TCNQF4. While this did not lead to isolation of fractionally reduced materials, intriguingly, only a semiconducting polymorph β (2) was obtained, rather than polymorph α (1) or a mixture of polymorphs. The yield of polymorph β (2) increased in proportion to the percentage TCNQF4 present. The resultant mixture was stirred for 1 h under N2 and filtered to remove the precipitate. The filtrate was diffused with diethyl ether, yielding blue, single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis (28 mg, 82%, based on LiTCNQF4). FTIR (ν/cm-1): 3105 (w), 2193 (s), 2176 (s), 2168 (m), 1634 (m), 1592 (m), 1538 (m), 1498 (m), 1488(m), 1414 (w), 1383 (s), 1347 (m), 1337 (m), 1264 (w), 1241 (w), 1200 (m), 1142 (m), 1065 (w), 1013 (w), 969 (s), 873 (m), 860 (m), 805 (w), 788 (w), 716(w). UV-vis (CH3CN): λmax; 262, 412, 753 (nm). Elemental analysis: for [Cp2Co]TCNQF4, C22H10N4F4Co, 465.27, Calcd (%): C: 56.79%, H: 2.17%, N: 12.04%. Found: C: 56.57%, H: 2.31%; N: 12.20%.

elements.content: Microanalyses were carried out at the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratories, University of Otago, New Zealand. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded using a Spectra Diamond ATR instrument. UV–vis spectra were obtained with a Cary 5 spectrophotometer, running on Varian OS2 software. X-ray structural data obtained from single crystals of [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 (1 and 2) and [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) (3) were collected at the Australian Synchrotron using the MX1 beamline operating at 15 keV (λ = 0.712 Å). A very small crystal was mounted on a cryoloop and then flash cooled to 100 K. The MX1 end station comprised a phi goniostat and ADSC Quantum 210r 210 × 210 mm large area detector. Because of hardware constraints (fixed detector angle), the maximum available data resolution on MX1 was limited to approximately 0.80 Å at the detector edges. The collection temperature was maintained at 100 K using an openflow N2 cryostream. Data were processed with the XDS software package. The structures were solved using direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined using conventional alternating least-squares methods with SHELXL-97 with the program OLEX2 as a graphical interface. All hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Theoretical powder diffraction patterns were calculated from the single-crystal X-ray data using Mercury software.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Characterization Procedures

Microanalyses were carried out at the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratories, University of Otago, New Zealand. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded using a Spectra Diamond ATR instrument. UV-vis spectra were obtained with a Cary 5 spectrophotometer, running on Varian OS2 software. X-ray structural data obtained from single crystals of [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 (1 and 2) and [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4) (3) were collected at the Australian Synchrotron using the MX1 beamline operating at 15 keV (λ = 0.712 Å). A very small crystal was mounted on a cryoloop and then flash cooled to 100 K. The MX1 end station comprised a phi goniostat and ADSC Quantum 210r 210 × 210 mm large area detector. Because of hardware constraints (fixed detector angle), the maximum available data resolution on MX1 was limited to approximately 0.80 Å at the detector edges. The collection temperature was maintained at 100 K using an openflow N2 cryostream. Data were processed with the XDS software package. The structures were solved using direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined using conventional alternating least-squares methods with SHELXL-97 with the program OLEX2  as a graphical interface. All hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Theoretical powder diffraction patterns were calculated from the single-crystal X-ray data using Mercury software.

elements.content: Voltammetric experiments used a standard three-electrode cell and were conducted at 20 ± 2 °C with a Bioanalytical Systems BASi Epsilon-EC electrochemical workstation. Glassy carbon macrodisc (1 mm in diameter, Bioanalytical Systems) or platinum microdisc electrodes (10 μm, Cypress) were used as the working electrodes. Prior to use, these electrodes were polished with 0.3 and 0.05 μm aqueous alumina slurries, rinsed with distilled water and acetone, and then dried with nitrogen gas. A platinum wire was used as the counter electrode. A silver wire immersed in a solution containing 0.1 M Bu4NPF6 in acetonitrile (separated from the test solution by a salt bridge) was used as a quasi-reference electrode. The Fc0/+ couple (Fc = ferrocene) was used as an internal calibrant. Potentials are reported vs Fc0/+. All solutions were degassed with nitrogen for 10 min prior to undertaking voltammetric experiments. A three-electrode cell containing a platinum-mesh working electrode, platinum gauze as the counter electrode, and a quasi-reference electrode (as described above) with each compartment being separated by a glass frit was used to perform reductive bulk electrolysis.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Procedures and Instrumentation

Voltammetric experiments used a standard three-electrode cell and were conducted at 20 ± 2 °C with a Bioanalytical Systems BASi Epsilon-EC electrochemical workstation. Glassy carbon macrodisc (1 mm in diameter, Bioanalytical Systems) or platinum microdisc electrodes (10 μm, Cypress) were used as the working electrodes. Prior to use, these electrodes were polished with 0.3 and 0.05 μm aqueous alumina slurries, rinsed with distilled water and acetone, and then dried with nitrogen gas. A platinum wire was used as the counter electrode. A silver wire immersed in a solution containing 0.1 M Bu4NPF6 in acetonitrile (separated from the test solution by a salt bridge) was used as a quasi-reference electrode. The Fc0/+ couple (Fc = ferrocene) was used as an internal calibrant. Potentials are reported vs Fc0/+. All solutions were degassed with nitrogen for 10 min prior to undertaking voltammetric experiments. A three-electrode cell containing a platinum-mesh working electrode, platinum gauze as the counter electrode, and a quasi-reference electrode (as described above) with each compartment being separated by a glass frit was used to perform reductive bulk electrolysis.

elements.content: Ideally, a conductivity measurement should be undertaken using a four-point probe method over a wide range of temperatures. This needs a relatively large and robust crystal. Such properties are rarely found in the TCNQ­(F4) field. We were able to achieve such conductivity data on (n-Bu4N)2­(TCNQ)5, but even then, the fragile nature of these crystals proved to be experimentally challenging. In the crystals reported here, they proved too small and fragile for single-crystal studies. Thus, we have used a chronoamperometric method and pressed pellets. These pellets 1 and 2 were placed across the (0.6 mm) gap between two gold strips and gently clamped to secure good electrical contact. The resistance measurements on these pellets were carried out by the DC technique of chronoamperometry (VMP3 potentiostat from BioLogic) over a range of voltage steps at 20 ± 2 °C. The calculated resistance (from R = V/I) was constant in the voltage range used, indicating a simple ohmic resistor. The resistance measured was in the 13 kΩ range, which means that the contribution from the gold strips (2.5 Ω) was negligible compared to the resistance of the pellets. The conductivity (σ) was then calculated as σ = t/(R × A), where t is the gap between the gold strips and A is the area of the pellets. The limitations of using a pellet instead of a single crystal are that there could be crystal boundaries and defects present, and thus the conductivity value obtained need not reflect the intrinsic electrical properties of the material. However, these measurements provide semiquantitative values that have enabled us to make a clear distinction between the conductivity of polymorphs 1 and 2.

elements.content: Polymorph α [Cp2Co]­CNQF4 (1) was synthesized by mixing a CH3CN solution of [Cp2Co]­PF6 with a CH3OH solution of LiTCNQF4 in a 1:1 molar ratio, and the resulting solution was diffused with diethyl ether to yield X-ray crystallographic quality crystals with a yield of 82%. Addition of 10% neutral TCNQF4 to this solution induced polymorph β (2) to crystallize with 82% yield as described in the . Lower yields of polymorph β were obtained using 2.5% or 5% neutral TCNQF4. [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) (3) was prepared in a manner similar to the [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 polymorph α (1) but used Li2TCNQF4 instead of LiTCNQF4. Dark orange crystals resulted in a ∼40% yield. All three complexes were characterized by X-ray crystallography, FTIR and UV–vis spectroscopy and electrochemistry. Furthermore, the elemental analyses of (1, 2 and 3) are consistent with the formulas [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 (1 and 2) and [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) (3).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses of [Cp2Co]-TCNQF4 Compounds

Polymorph α [Cp2Co]CNQF4 (1) was synthesized by mixing a CH3CN solution of [Cp2Co]PF6 with a CH3OH solution of LiTCNQF4 in a 1:1 molar ratio, and the resulting solution was diffused with diethyl ether to yield X-ray crystallographic quality crystals with a yield of 82%. Addition of 10% neutral TCNQF4 to this solution induced polymorph β (2) to crystallize with 82% yield as described in the . Lower yields of polymorph β were obtained using 2.5% or 5% neutral TCNQF4. [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4) (3) was prepared in a manner similar to the [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 polymorph α (1) but used Li2TCNQF4 instead of LiTCNQF4. Dark orange crystals resulted in a ~40% yield. All three complexes were characterized by X-ray crystallography, FTIR and UV-vis spectroscopy and electrochemistry. Furthermore, the elemental analyses of (1, 2 and 3) are consistent with the formulas [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 (1 and 2) and [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4) (3).

elements.content: Crystallographic data from the X-ray structures of the three complexes (1, 2, and 3) are provided in . CCDC numbers are 1575753 (1), 1575759 (2), and 1850731 (3). Full crystallographic data for 1, 2, and 3 are available on request from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K. (http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Single-Crystal X-ray Structures

Crystallographic data from the X-ray structures of the three complexes (1, 2, and 3) are provided in . CCDC numbers are 1575753 (1), 1575759 (2), and 1850731 (3). Full crystallographic data for 1, 2, and 3 are available on request from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K. (http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Analysis of the mean bond lengths in [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 obtained by using the Kistenmacher relationship [ρ = A[c/(b + d)] + B] (A = −46.729 and B = 22.308), where A and B were determined for neutral TCNQF4 (ρ = 0) and TCNQF4 1– monoanion in n-Bu4NTCNQF4 (ρ = 1−)], showed that the anion was in the reduced form, i.e., TCNQF4 1– (Table S1). The asymmetric units of both polymorph α, 1, and polymorph β, 2, contain one TCNQF4 1– anion and one cobaltocenium cation, but in different alignments, as shown in , panels a and b, respectively. The crystallographic details for the polymorphs are discussed below.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of the Two Polymorphs of [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 

Analysis of the mean bond lengths in [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 obtained by using the Kistenmacher relationship [ρ = A[c/(b + d)] + B] (A = -46.729 and B = 22.308), where A and B were determined for neutral TCNQF4 (ρ = 0) and TCNQF4 1- monoanion in n-Bu4NTCNQF4 (ρ = 1-)], showed that the anion was in the reduced form, i.e., TCNQF4 1- (Table S1). The asymmetric units of both polymorph α, 1, and polymorph β, 2, contain one TCNQF4 1- anion and one cobaltocenium cation, but in different alignments, as shown in , panels a and b, respectively. The crystallographic details for the polymorphs are discussed below.

elements.content: Molecular structure showing the asymmetric unit of (a) the [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 polymorph α (1) and (b) polymorph β.
elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structure showing the asymmetric unit of (a) the [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 polymorph α (1) and (b) polymorph β.

elements.content: Polymorph α (1) crystallized in a monoclinic unit cell with a space group P21/c. The TCNQF4 anion and the plane of the two Cp rings in the cation are close to perpendicular to each other (88.81° and 87.46°, respectively), interacting via H-bonding; (Cp2Co)­H1···N1C­(TCNQF4) with 2.327(2) Å and (Cp2Co)­H6···F2­(TCNQF4) with 2.4157 (19) Å as shown in a.
elements.clean_text: Polymorph α (1) crystallized in a monoclinic unit cell with a space group P21/c. The TCNQF4 anion and the plane of the two Cp rings in the cation are close to perpendicular to each other (88.81° and 87.46°, respectively), interacting via H-bonding; (Cp2Co)H1⋅⋅⋅N1C(TCNQF4) with 2.327(2) Å and (Cp2Co)H6⋅⋅⋅F2(TCNQF4) with 2.4157 (19) Å as shown in a.

elements.content: In the cation, the two Cp ring planes are not completely parallel to one another, lying at an angle of 2.58°. Further, the H atoms of the two Cp rings are almost, but not fully, eclipsed. The TCNQF4 1– anion is not planar but rather twisted.
elements.clean_text: In the cation, the two Cp ring planes are not completely parallel to one another, lying at an angle of 2.58°. Further, the H atoms of the two Cp rings are almost, but not fully, eclipsed. The TCNQF4 1- anion is not planar but rather twisted.

elements.content: The crystal packing consists of alternating layers of TCNQF4 1– anions and cobaltocenium cations. A view of the alternating layers of [Cp2Co]+ and TCNQF4 1– anions in the unit cell is shown in . The neighboring TCNQF4 1– ions form a pair resulting from the π–π interaction (interplanar angle 0.00° and shift distance 0.863 Å) with the shortest distance 3.154(2) Å and intercentroid distance of 3.215 Å. The overlap mode is the ring over exocyclic CC bond, which is often observed in TCNQF4 1– dimers. A neighboring pair of TCNQF4 1– is orientated at an angle of 83.43°, so there are no π–π interactions between these two TCNQF4 1– pairs. Neighboring [Cp2Co]+ cations have a Co–Co distance of 6.258 Å. The arrangement of [Cp2Co]+ cations and TCNQF4 1– anions in the unit cell of polymorph α is shown in .
elements.clean_text: The crystal packing consists of alternating layers of TCNQF4 1- anions and cobaltocenium cations. A view of the alternating layers of [Cp2Co]+ and TCNQF4 1- anions in the unit cell is shown in . The neighboring TCNQF4 1- ions form a pair resulting from the π-π interaction (interplanar angle 0.00° and shift distance 0.863 Å) with the shortest distance 3.154(2) Å and intercentroid distance of 3.215 Å. The overlap mode is the ring over exocyclic CC bond, which is often observed in TCNQF4 1- dimers. A neighboring pair of TCNQF4 1- is orientated at an angle of 83.43°, so there are no π-π interactions between these two TCNQF4 1- pairs. Neighboring [Cp2Co]+ cations have a Co-Co distance of 6.258 Å. The arrangement of [Cp2Co]+ cations and TCNQF4 1- anions in the unit cell of polymorph α is shown in .

elements.content: Crystal packing in [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 polymorph α (1) showing alternating layers of [Cp2Co]+ cations and TCNQF4 1– anions, in the packing in the unit cell.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal packing in [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 polymorph α (1) showing alternating layers of [Cp2Co]+ cations and TCNQF4 1- anions, in the packing in the unit cell.

elements.content: [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4, polymorph β (2), was crystallized from a methanol solution of LiTCNQF4 containing 10% TCNQF4 and [Cp2Co]­PF6. The monoclinic asymmetric unit (P21/n) of 2 contains one TCNQF4 1– anion and one [Cp2Co]+ cation, as in 1 but in a different alignment as shown in b. TCNQF4 1– and the [Cp2Co]+ interact through strong H-bonding involving (Cp2Co)­H1···N3C­(TCNQF4) with 2.6422(5) Å and (Cp2Co)­H6···N4C­(TCNQF4) with 2.6507(4) Å (see b). Two Cp rings of the [Cp2Co]+ cation are almost parallel with an angle of 0.55°, and the protons on the two Cp rings are fully eclipsed. The TCNQF4 1– anions are not planar, but twisted as in 1. However, in contrast to polymorph α, 1, the packing of polymorph β, 2, consists of isolated columns of cobaltocenium cations and TCNQF4 1– anions with π–π interactions (a,b). Two types of π–π interactions are observed for TCNQF4 1–. One is the ring-based face-to-face π–π interaction (interplanar angle 0.00° and intercentroid shift distance 0.769 Å) which forms a pair of TCNQF4 1– with the shortest distance being 3.179 Å and intercentroid distance of 3.248 Å. A second π–π interaction occurs between two pairs of TCNQF4 1–, which are further apart with an intercentroid distance of 3.501 Å (interplanar angle 0.00° and shift distance 1.148 Å) as highlighted in b.
elements.clean_text: [Cp2Co]TCNQF4, polymorph β (2), was crystallized from a methanol solution of LiTCNQF4 containing 10% TCNQF4 and [Cp2Co]PF6. The monoclinic asymmetric unit (P21/n) of 2 contains one TCNQF4 1- anion and one [Cp2Co]+ cation, as in 1 but in a different alignment as shown in b. TCNQF4 1- and the [Cp2Co]+ interact through strong H-bonding involving (Cp2Co)H1⋅⋅⋅N3C(TCNQF4) with 2.6422(5) Å and (Cp2Co)H6⋅⋅⋅N4C(TCNQF4) with 2.6507(4) Å (see b). Two Cp rings of the [Cp2Co]+ cation are almost parallel with an angle of 0.55°, and the protons on the two Cp rings are fully eclipsed. The TCNQF4 1- anions are not planar, but twisted as in 1. However, in contrast to polymorph α, 1, the packing of polymorph β, 2, consists of isolated columns of cobaltocenium cations and TCNQF4 1- anions with π-π interactions (a,b). Two types of π-π interactions are observed for TCNQF4 1-. One is the ring-based face-to-face π-π interaction (interplanar angle 0.00° and intercentroid shift distance 0.769 Å) which forms a pair of TCNQF4 1- with the shortest distance being 3.179 Å and intercentroid distance of 3.248 Å. A second π-π interaction occurs between two pairs of TCNQF4 1-, which are further apart with an intercentroid distance of 3.501 Å (interplanar angle 0.00° and shift distance 1.148 Å) as highlighted in b.

elements.content: Crystal packing in polymorph β (2) of [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 showing segregated columns of TCNQF4 1– and [Cp2Co]+ formed by π–π interactions (a) view along the a-axis (b) view along the b-axis.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal packing in polymorph β (2) of [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 showing segregated columns of TCNQF4 1- and [Cp2Co]+ formed by π-π interactions (a) view along the a-axis (b) view along the b-axis.

elements.content: The alignment of the TCNQF4 1– pair leads to short distances (3.179 Å), consistent with good electronic conductivity. Between the anion columns of TCNQF4 1– lie the neighboring [Cp2Co]+ columns that form chains along the a-axis as in b. These chains are derived from face-to-face ring π–π interactions between neighboring Cp rings with an interplanar centroid–centroid distance of 3.4680(7) Å (a). However, no additional interactions between these [Cp2Co]+ chains were identified. The distances between the metal ions (Co3+) of neighboring [Cp2Co]+ cations are 6.7400(13) Å within the chain and 7.5742(12) Å for a neighboring chain, respectively. a,b shows the view along the a-axis and b-axis, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The alignment of the TCNQF4 1- pair leads to short distances (3.179 Å), consistent with good electronic conductivity. Between the anion columns of TCNQF4 1- lie the neighboring [Cp2Co]+ columns that form chains along the a-axis as in b. These chains are derived from face-to-face ring π-π interactions between neighboring Cp rings with an interplanar centroid-centroid distance of 3.4680(7) Å (a). However, no additional interactions between these [Cp2Co]+ chains were identified. The distances between the metal ions (Co3+) of neighboring [Cp2Co]+ cations are 6.7400(13) Å within the chain and 7.5742(12) Å for a neighboring chain, respectively. a,b shows the view along the a-axis and b-axis, respectively.

elements.content: Powder X-ray patterns were calculated using the X-ray single-crystal data for each polymorph α and β. The comparison shown in Figure S1 clearly illustrates the significant difference between their structures.
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray patterns were calculated using the X-ray single-crystal data for each polymorph α and β. The comparison shown in Figure S1 clearly illustrates the significant difference between their structures.

elements.content: The reaction employing Li2TCNQF4 and [Cp2Co]+ gave crystals of [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) (3) in the orthorhombic space group Cmce. The asymmetric unit consists of half the [Cp2Co]+ cation and half of the TCNQF4 2– dianion coordinated to a Li+ cation as shown in a. The bond lengths for TCNQF4 2– are consistent with the doubly reduced form (Table S1). Thus, the formula of 3 is [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4), and this agrees with the elemental analysis. The two Cp rings of the cation are close to parallel with a dihedral angle of 2.2°.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4) (3)

The reaction employing Li2TCNQF4 and [Cp2Co]+ gave crystals of [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4) (3) in the orthorhombic space group Cmce. The asymmetric unit consists of half the [Cp2Co]+ cation and half of the TCNQF4 2- dianion coordinated to a Li+ cation as shown in a. The bond lengths for TCNQF4 2- are consistent with the doubly reduced form (Table S1). Thus, the formula of 3 is [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4), and this agrees with the elemental analysis. The two Cp rings of the cation are close to parallel with a dihedral angle of 2.2°.

elements.content: (a) Asymmetrical unit of 3 (b) showing a distorted tetrahedral arrangement around the Li cation. 50% thermal ellipsoids are displayed. H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Asymmetrical unit of 3 (b) showing a distorted tetrahedral arrangement around the Li cation. 50% thermal ellipsoids are displayed. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In the crystal packing diagram, each Li+ cation coordinates with four different TCNQF4 2– dianions, via N atoms from the nitrile group, to give a distorted tetrahedral geometry with two NLiN angles of 100.43° and the remaining two of 120.66°, as shown in b. All four CN groups of TCNQF4 2– coordinate further with four different Li+ cations in this distorted tetrahedral geometry. This direct bonding between the Li+ and the TCNQF4 2– leads to a unique metal–organic framework that creates loops and pockets to accommodate the organometallic cation [Cp2Co]+ as displayed in a (viewed down the b-axis), in b with space filled model of [Cp2Co]+ cations in the loops/pockets of Li+-TCNQF4 2– network, and in c (viewed down the a-axis). Neighboring [Cp2Co]+ cations form a pair via π–π interactions with an interplanar distance of 3.283 Å and intercentroid distance of 3.289 Å. The distance between cobalt ions in the [Cp2Co]+ cations is 6.551 Å. The neighboring [Cp2Co]+ pairs orientate at an angle of 76.73°, and H-bonding between (TCNQF4)­N2···H14­(Cp2Co) forms an elegant three-dimensional (3D) network.
elements.clean_text: In the crystal packing diagram, each Li+ cation coordinates with four different TCNQF4 2- dianions, via N atoms from the nitrile group, to give a distorted tetrahedral geometry with two NLiN angles of 100.43° and the remaining two of 120.66°, as shown in b. All four CN groups of TCNQF4 2- coordinate further with four different Li+ cations in this distorted tetrahedral geometry. This direct bonding between the Li+ and the TCNQF4 2- leads to a unique metal-organic framework that creates loops and pockets to accommodate the organometallic cation [Cp2Co]+ as displayed in a (viewed down the b-axis), in b with space filled model of [Cp2Co]+ cations in the loops/pockets of Li+-TCNQF4 2- network, and in c (viewed down the a-axis). Neighboring [Cp2Co]+ cations form a pair via π-π interactions with an interplanar distance of 3.283 Å and intercentroid distance of 3.289 Å. The distance between cobalt ions in the [Cp2Co]+ cations is 6.551 Å. The neighboring [Cp2Co]+ pairs orientate at an angle of 76.73°, and H-bonding between (TCNQF4)N2⋅⋅⋅H14(Cp2Co) forms an elegant three-dimensional (3D) network.

elements.content: (a) Showing the loops/pockets formed by direct bonding between Li+ and TCNQF4 2– with the loops accommodating [Cp2Co]+ cations, (b) view showing space-filled model of [Cp2Co]+ cations in the loops/pockets of the Li+-TCNQF4 2– network (c) view down the a-axis showing the arrangement of [Cp2Co]+. Color code for panel (a): light blue: Li+, dark blue: Co, blue: N, green: F, dark gray: C and white: H.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Showing the loops/pockets formed by direct bonding between Li+ and TCNQF4 2- with the loops accommodating [Cp2Co]+ cations, (b) view showing space-filled model of [Cp2Co]+ cations in the loops/pockets of the Li+-TCNQF4 2- network (c) view down the a-axis showing the arrangement of [Cp2Co]+. Color code for panel (a): light blue: Li+, dark blue: Co, blue: N, green: F, dark gray: C and white: H.

elements.content: In the case of [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 polymorph β, similar crystal packing has been reported for the [Cp2Fe]­TCNQF4 derivative with segregated columns of TCNQF4 1– and [Cp2Fe]+. In this material, TCNQF4 1– anions form a pair with the interplanar distance being 3.225 Å, and these pairs further interact at 3.675 Å, a distance slightly longer than observed in the present example. In another study, this type of packing was observed for TCNQF4 2– salts such as (dpx)­TCNQF4, (dpicx)­TCNQF4, and (diqx)­TCNQF4 where dpx = (dipyridinum)­xylene; dpicx = di­(picolinium)­xylene and diqx = di­(isoquinoline)­xylene.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of Structures with Related Compounds

In the case of [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 polymorph β, similar crystal packing has been reported for the [Cp2Fe]TCNQF4 derivative with segregated columns of TCNQF4 1- and [Cp2Fe]+. In this material, TCNQF4 1- anions form a pair with the interplanar distance being 3.225 Å, and these pairs further interact at 3.675 Å, a distance slightly longer than observed in the present example. In another study, this type of packing was observed for TCNQF4 2- salts such as (dpx)TCNQF4, (dpicx)TCNQF4, and (diqx)TCNQF4 where dpx = (dipyridinum)xylene; dpicx = di(picolinium)xylene and diqx = di(isoquinoline)xylene.

elements.content: In the case of [(Me5Cp)2Fe]+ with the TCNQ anion, Miller et al. have characterized [(Me5Cp)2Fe]­TCNQ in two polymorphs (in their paper, referred to as different phases), which are not structurally related to our [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 polymorphs α and β. As mentioned in the introduction, the Miller group also isolated and characterized the dianionic derivative {[(Me5Cp)2M]}2­(TCNQF4) (M = Fe, Co) and {[(Me5Cp)2Co]}2­(TCNQI2) all of which are structurally related. However, the X-ray crystal of [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) (3) is of course structurally different with the introduction of Li+ creating a 3D network to accommodate the TCNQF4 2– anion.
elements.clean_text: In the case of [(Me5Cp)2Fe]+ with the TCNQ anion, Miller et al. have characterized [(Me5Cp)2Fe]TCNQ in two polymorphs (in their paper, referred to as different phases), which are not structurally related to our [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 polymorphs α and β. As mentioned in the introduction, the Miller group also isolated and characterized the dianionic derivative {[(Me5Cp)2M]}2(TCNQF4) (M = Fe, Co) and {[(Me5Cp)2Co]}2(TCNQI2) all of which are structurally related. However, the X-ray crystal of [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4) (3) is of course structurally different with the introduction of Li+ creating a 3D network to accommodate the TCNQF4 2- anion.

elements.content: FTIR spectra show characteristic frequencies, which provide a useful tool for identifying the redox level of TCNQF4 derivatives, especially in the nitrile stretching region. FTIR spectra of [Cp2Co]-TCNQF4 materials (1, 2, and 3) are shown in Figures S2–S5 (Supporting Information). Although the FTIR spectra of (1 and 2) are similar to each other, some important differences are evident, presumably because the different crystal packing provides different environments. The CN stretches observed at 2191, 2179, and 2166 cm–1 for 1 and 2193, 2176, and 2168 cm–1 for 2 are lower than found in neutral TCNQF4 (2228 cm–1) and are characteristic of the TCNQF4 1– radical anion. However, the relative intensities of these bands differ, indicating that the CN groups of (1 and 2) are in different environments (Figure S3). In the [Cp2Co]+­TCNQF4 1– polymorph α, the bands at 1535 and 1496, cm–1 corresponding to the CC ring and exocyclic CC vibrations are detected at significantly lower frequencies than in neutral TCNQF4 (1600 and 1551 cm–1), as is once again characteristic of the monoanionic reduced TCNQF4 1–. Other diagnostic bands at 1382 and 1347 cm–1 are due to the C–F and ring C–C stretches, also consistent with the TCNQF4 1– radical anion. For [Cp2Co]-TCNQF4 polymorph β, the two bands at 1594 and 1538 cm–1 associated with the CC ring, and the band at 1498 with a shoulder at 1488 cm–1 are due to the exocyclic CC stretches. The bands at 1383, 1347, and 1337 cm–1 also correspond to C–F and ring C–C stretches. In the FTIR spectrum of polymorph β (2), the presence of extra bands (1594, 1488, and 1337 cm–1) may be due to differences in crystal packing. However, overall the IR spectra are consistent with the TCNQF4 1– radical anion. In the [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4), (3), complex, the CN stretches at 2202, 2175, 2151, 2134, and 2106 cm–1 were observed, all consistent with the presence of TCNQF4 2– dianion. The ring CC stretching frequencies give diagnostic bands at 1489 and 1478 cm–1, which are at lower frequencies compared with the neutral TCNQF4 (1600 and 1551 cm–1) and TCNQF4 1– (1535 and 1500 cm–1) radical anion. A weak band at 1312 cm–1 is attributed to the C–F and ring C–C stretch for 3. Overall, the FTIR spectrum of 3 confirms that the reduced dianionic TCNQF4 2– moiety is present.

Vibrational (FTIR) Spectroscopy

FTIR spectra show characteristic frequencies, which provide a useful tool for identifying the redox level of TCNQF4 derivatives, especially in the nitrile stretching region. FTIR spectra of [Cp2Co]-TCNQF4 materials (1, 2, and 3) are shown in Figures S2-S5 (Supporting Information). Although the FTIR spectra of (1 and 2) are similar to each other, some important differences are evident, presumably because the different crystal packing provides different environments. The CN stretches observed at 2191, 2179, and 2166 cm-1 for 1 and 2193, 2176, and 2168 cm-1 for 2 are lower than found in neutral TCNQF4 (2228 cm-1) and are characteristic of the TCNQF4 1- radical anion. However, the relative intensities of these bands differ, indicating that the CN groups of (1 and 2) are in different environments (Figure S3). In the [Cp2Co]+TCNQF4 1- polymorph α, the bands at 1535 and 1496, cm-1 corresponding to the CC ring and exocyclic CC vibrations are detected at significantly lower frequencies than in neutral TCNQF4 (1600 and 1551 cm-1), as is once again characteristic of the monoanionic reduced TCNQF4 1-. Other diagnostic bands at 1382 and 1347 cm-1 are due to the C-F and ring C-C stretches, also consistent with the TCNQF4 1- radical anion. For [Cp2Co]-TCNQF4 polymorph β, the two bands at 1594 and 1538 cm-1 associated with the CC ring, and the band at 1498 with a shoulder at 1488 cm-1 are due to the exocyclic CC stretches. The bands at 1383, 1347, and 1337 cm-1 also correspond to C-F and ring C-C stretches. In the FTIR spectrum of polymorph β (2), the presence of extra bands (1594, 1488, and 1337 cm-1) may be due to differences in crystal packing. However, overall the IR spectra are consistent with the TCNQF4 1- radical anion. In the [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4), (3), complex, the CN stretches at 2202, 2175, 2151, 2134, and 2106 cm-1 were observed, all consistent with the presence of TCNQF4 2- dianion. The ring CC stretching frequencies give diagnostic bands at 1489 and 1478 cm-1, which are at lower frequencies compared with the neutral TCNQF4 (1600 and 1551 cm-1) and TCNQF4 1- (1535 and 1500 cm-1) radical anion. A weak band at 1312 cm-1 is attributed to the C-F and ring C-C stretch for 3. Overall, the FTIR spectrum of 3 confirms that the reduced dianionic TCNQF4 2- moiety is present.

elements.clean_text:
Solution Phase Voltammetry of (1, 2, and 3)

The electrochemistry of solutions of (1, 2, and 3) in CH3CN (0.1 M Bu4NPF6) was studied initially by transient cyclic voltammetry at a glassy carbon macrodisc electrode.  The scan rate dependence of voltammograms of (1) and (3) are shown in Figure S6 (a) and (b) in Supporting Information, respectively.

elements.content: The cyclic voltammogram obtained at a scan rate of 200 mVs–1 for 0.38 mM of (3), [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) in CH3CN (0.1 M Bu4NPF6) shown in a, displays two reversible, diffusion-controlled, one-electron oxidation processes and a reversible reduction process. These processes correspond to sequential oxidation of TCNQF4 2– to TCNQF4 1– () and then to TCNQF4 0 () and reduction of [Cp2Co]+ to [Cp2Co]0 (). The midpoint potentials are E m1 = −0.33 mV, E m2 = 0.19 mV, and E m3 = −1.33 mV (vs Fc0/+), where E m is the average of the reduction (E p red) and oxidation (E p ox) peak potentials and represents a close approximation of the reversible formal potential E 0 f. The separation in the potentials for the two TCNQF4-based oxidation processes is 0.52 V and is consistent with literature data reported under similar conditions. A scan rate study for the oxidation step over the range of 50–1000 mV s–1 is shown in Figure S6b in Supporting Information. These voltammetric data imply that upon dissolution of (3) in CH3CN, TCNQF4 2– and [Cp2Co]+ are formed with both species being stable on the time-scale of these studies.

elements.content: Steady-state voltammetry obtained at a microdisc electrode was used to confirm the redox level of TCNQF4 2– in (3) (b). Only oxidation current associated with the TCNQF4 2–/1– and TCNQF4 1–/0 processes is detected, implying the presence of TCNQF4 2– dianion in the solid (3). The half-wave potential ( E 1/2) values are −0.34 and 0.19 V vs Fc0/+ for TCNQF4 2–/1– and TCNQF4 1–/0 processes, respectively, and in agreement with E m values, as expected for a reversible process.

elements.content: The voltammetric behavior of the two polymorphs of [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4, dissolved in acetonitrile solution, is identical. A transient cyclic voltammogram obtained at a scan rate of 100 mV s–1 for 1.0 mM of (1) in CH3CN (0.1 M Bu4NPF6) is shown in a and displays two TCNQF4-based diffusion-controlled, electrochemically and chemically reversible processes. The scan rate dependence of (1) is shown in Figure S6­(a) of the Supporting Information. In this case, the first TCNQF4-based process is for reduction of TCNQF4 1– to TCNQF4 2– () followed by the process for oxidation of TCNQF4 1– to TCNQF4 0 (). The midpoint potentials are E m1 = −0.36 V and E m2 = 0.18 V (vs Fc0/+). The separation in the potentials for the two processes is again 0.52 V and consistent with the literature. A reversible [Cp2Co]+/0 reduction process is also detected (data not shown) and is derived from the reaction in . These voltammetric data imply that upon dissolution of 1 in CH3CN, TCNQF4 1– and [Cp2Co]+ are formed.

elements.content: Reductive bulk electrolysis was performed on 5.0 mL of a 1.0 mM TCNQF4 0 acetonitrile solution (0.1 M Bu4NPF6) by applying a potential of 0.064 V vs Fc0/+. The color changed from yellow (TCNQF4 0) to green (TCNQF4 1–). Near steady-state voltammograms, before (red, TCNQF4 0) and after bulk electrolysis (black, TCNQF4 1–), are shown in a. Addition of solid [Cp2Co]­PF6 to give an equimolar acetonitrile solution gave voltammetry identical to that for a 1.0 mM [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4, (1 and 2). Near steady-state voltammograms of this solution (b) reveal that the zero current position lies midway between the TCNQF4 1–/0 oxidation and TCNQF4 1–/2– reduction processes. Transient cyclic voltammetry over a wider potential range than (a) and (b) shows the [Cp2Co]+/0 cobalt-based reduction process (c).

elements.content: UV–vis spectra of 1, 2, 3, and [Cp2Co]­PF6 dissolved in CH3CN are shown in . Both (1 and 2) exhibit absorption bands with λmax values of 261, 412, and 754 nm, which are characteristic of the TCNQF4 1– radical anion. In the case of 3, the spectrum is dominated by three intense absorption bands with λmax at 219, 333, and 261 nm which are assigned to the TCNQF4 2– dianion and the [Cp2Co]+ cation. These results are consistent with previous reports and confirm the conclusions reached from structural, vibrational, and electrochemical studies.

Electronic (UV-vis) Spectroscopy

UV-vis spectra of 1, 2, 3, and [Cp2Co]PF6 dissolved in CH3CN are shown in . Both (1 and 2) exhibit absorption bands with λmax values of 261, 412, and 754 nm, which are characteristic of the TCNQF4 1- radical anion. In the case of 3, the spectrum is dominated by three intense absorption bands with λmax at 219, 333, and 261 nm which are assigned to the TCNQF4 2-  dianion and the [Cp2Co]+ cation. These results are consistent with previous reports and confirm the conclusions reached from structural, vibrational, and electrochemical studies.

elements.content: The DC conductivities of 1 and 2 were measured using a method previously reported, which is summarized in the . Polymorph α (1) did not give a current output for a range of applied voltages (up to 10 V on both Au and FTO electrodes), indicating that 1 is nonconducting at room temperature. In contrast, the calculated conductivity at room temperature of 2 was 5.8 × 10–4 S cm–1, which is well within the semiconducting range (see Figure S7). This result is consistent with the crystal packing in 2 where TCNQF4 1– and [Cp2Co]+ are arranged in segregated columns, leading to higher conductivity than (1), which is composed of alternating layers of TCNQF4 1– and [Cp2Co]+. The limitation of this method versus the ideal four-point probe method of a single crystal and over a range temperatures is summarized in the experimental. However, even though we obtained small crystals suitable for X-ray analysis, these were not amenable for four-point probe conductivity. Nevertheless, a clear distinction between the conductivity of polymorphs 1 and 2 was demonstrated using the chronoamperometric technique.
elements.clean_text:
Conductivity of Polymorphs α and β, [Cp2Co]TCNQF4, (1 and 2)

The DC conductivities of 1 and 2 were measured using a method previously reported, which is summarized in the . Polymorph α (1) did not give a current output for a range of applied voltages (up to 10 V on both Au and FTO electrodes), indicating that 1 is nonconducting at room temperature. In contrast, the calculated conductivity at room temperature of 2 was 5.8 × 10-4 S cm-1, which is well within the semiconducting range (see Figure S7). This result is consistent with the crystal packing in 2 where TCNQF4 1- and [Cp2Co]+ are arranged in segregated columns, leading to higher conductivity than (1), which is composed of alternating layers of TCNQF4 1- and [Cp2Co]+. The limitation of this method versus the ideal four-point probe method of a single crystal and over a range temperatures is summarized in the experimental. However, even though we obtained small crystals suitable for X-ray analysis, these were not amenable for four-point probe conductivity. Nevertheless, a clear distinction between the conductivity of polymorphs 1 and 2 was demonstrated using the chronoamperometric technique.

elements.content: It seems remarkable that synthesis of the two polymorphs by methods that differ only by the presence of a small percentage of neutral TCNQF4 can have such an impact on the structure and conductivity. Interestingly, in both cases, the yields are high and very similar. Polymorph α (1) is prepared by a direct metathesis reaction using a 1:1 mixture of the cation and anion, whereas in the case of polymorph β, the only difference is that neutral TCNQF4 is also present. In the extensive studies by Miller et al., all compounds were synthesized by redox chemistry involving oxidation of neutral [(Me5Cp)2M] (M = Fe, Co) and reduction of neutral TCNQ­(F4). [(Me5Cp)2Co] is a very powerful reductant relative to [Cp2Fe] ( reversible potentials for [Cp2Co]0/+ versus Fc0/+ process, which differ by −1.33 V). In the example of the [(Me5Cp)2Fe] reacting with TCNQ, use of equimolar mixtures produced two different [(Me5Cp)2Fe]­(TCNQ) structures. In the case of the synthesis of [(Me5Cp)2Fe]2­(TCNQ)2, a large excess (2:1) of TCNQ was used, which in principle could have led to the dianion as found for reaction with [(Me5Cp)2Co]+ to give [(Me5Cp)2Co]2­(TCNQ). However, in the ferrocene case, the reversible potentials are not sufficient to allow [(Me5Cp)2Fe] to reduce TCNQ to TCNQ2–. Thus, this synthesis took place under conditions where both TCNQ and TCNQ1– were present simultaneously to give [(Me5Cp)2Fe]2­(TCNQ) which was found to be semiconducting (0.1 S·cm–1). These reaction conditions mimic those used by us to prepare the moderately conducting 1:1 material, polymorph β. It is therefore plausible that transiently formed [Cp2Co]­(TCNQF4)2 disproportionates to [Cp2Co]­(TCNQF4) and TCNQF4, as shown in and . In this reaction sequence, the different morphology is imposed by the transient intermediate in , and “disproportionation” of {(TCNQF4)2}2– regenerates the neutral TCNQF4 allowing a high yield without consumption of TCNQF4.
elements.clean_text:
Origin of the Structural Change Induced by Addition of Neutral TCNQF4 

It seems remarkable that synthesis of the two polymorphs by methods that differ only by the presence of a small percentage of neutral TCNQF4 can have such an impact on the structure and conductivity. Interestingly, in both cases, the yields are high and very similar. Polymorph α (1) is prepared by a direct metathesis reaction using a 1:1 mixture of the cation and anion, whereas in the case of polymorph β, the only difference is that neutral TCNQF4 is also present. In the extensive studies by Miller et al., all compounds were synthesized by redox chemistry involving oxidation of neutral [(Me5Cp)2M] (M = Fe, Co) and reduction of neutral TCNQ(F4). [(Me5Cp)2Co] is a very powerful reductant relative to [Cp2Fe] ( reversible potentials for [Cp2Co]0/+ versus Fc0/+ process, which differ by -1.33 V). In the example of the [(Me5Cp)2Fe] reacting with TCNQ, use of equimolar mixtures produced two different [(Me5Cp)2Fe](TCNQ) structures. In the case of the synthesis of [(Me5Cp)2Fe]2(TCNQ)2, a large excess (2:1) of TCNQ was used, which in principle could have led to the dianion as found for reaction with [(Me5Cp)2Co]+ to give [(Me5Cp)2Co]2(TCNQ). However, in the ferrocene case, the reversible potentials are not sufficient to allow [(Me5Cp)2Fe] to reduce TCNQ to TCNQ2-. Thus, this synthesis took place under conditions where both TCNQ and TCNQ1- were present simultaneously to give [(Me5Cp)2Fe]2(TCNQ) which was found to be semiconducting (0.1 S⋅cm-1). These reaction conditions mimic those used by us to prepare the moderately conducting 1:1 material, polymorph β. It is therefore plausible that transiently formed [Cp2Co](TCNQF4)2 disproportionates to [Cp2Co](TCNQF4) and TCNQF4, as shown in  and . In this reaction sequence, the different morphology is imposed by the transient intermediate in , and "disproportionation" of {(TCNQF4)2}2- regenerates the neutral TCNQF4 allowing a high yield without consumption of TCNQF4.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that both the [(Me5Cp)2Fe]2­(TCNQ) and [Cp2Co]2­(TCNQF4), which we postulate are derived from related pathways, are both semiconducting. However, we would not be surprised if alternative mechanisms also could explain the remarkable observation that a small amount of TCNQ­(F4) would generate polymorphic materials with significantly different properties, e.g., conductivity, in high yields.
elements.clean_text: It is noteworthy that both the [(Me5Cp)2Fe]2(TCNQ) and [Cp2Co]2(TCNQF4), which we postulate are derived from related pathways, are both semiconducting. However, we would not be surprised if alternative mechanisms also could explain the remarkable observation that a small amount of TCNQ(F4) would generate polymorphic materials with significantly different properties, e.g., conductivity, in high yields.

elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of three new materials involving organic monoanionic TCNQF4 1– and dianionic TCNQF4 2– with the organometallic [Cp2Co]+ cation have been achieved. The monoanionic TCNQF4 1– complex [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 was crystallized in two polymorph forms α and β (1 and 2) in high yield, with the latter being semiconducting. Remarkably, the syntheses only differed by the presence of a small amount of neutral TCNQF4 in the case of polymorph β (2). The role of the TCNQF4 has been rationalized on the basis of a transient intermediate, postulated as [Cp2Co]­(TCNQF4)2. Support of this hypothesis is found in the analogous [(Me5Cp)2Fe]-TCNQ redox chemistry, where [(Me5Cp)2Fe]­(TCNQ)2 has been isolated. Examination of the solid state properties of 1 and 2 revealed that 2 has infinite parallel segregated columns of TCNQF4 1– and [Cp2Co]+, which make it a more conducting than 1, which has alternating layers of TCNQF4 1– and [Cp2Co]+. [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) (3) comprises both Li+ and [Cp2Co]+ cations along with the dianion TCNQF4 2–. Direct bonding of Li+ with TCNQF4 2– generates a metal–organic framework that can accommodate the [Cp2Co]+ cation. All three compounds have been further characterized by FTIR and UV–vis spectroscopy, electrochemically and by elemental analysis with all data being consistent with the formulations of [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4 (1 and 2) and [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) (3). Compound 3, containing dianionic TCNQF4 2–, is stable in air.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The synthesis and characterization of three new materials involving organic monoanionic TCNQF4 1- and dianionic TCNQF4 2- with the organometallic [Cp2Co]+ cation have been achieved. The monoanionic TCNQF4 1- complex [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 was crystallized in two polymorph forms α and β (1 and 2) in high yield, with the latter being semiconducting. Remarkably, the syntheses only differed by the presence of a small amount of neutral TCNQF4 in the case of polymorph β (2). The role of the TCNQF4 has been rationalized on the basis of a transient intermediate, postulated as [Cp2Co](TCNQF4)2. Support of this hypothesis is found in the analogous [(Me5Cp)2Fe]-TCNQ redox chemistry, where [(Me5Cp)2Fe](TCNQ)2  has been isolated. Examination of the solid state properties of 1 and 2 revealed that 2 has infinite parallel segregated columns of TCNQF4 1- and [Cp2Co]+, which make it a more conducting than 1, which has alternating layers of TCNQF4 1- and [Cp2Co]+. [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4) (3) comprises both Li+ and [Cp2Co]+ cations along with the dianion TCNQF4 2-. Direct bonding of Li+ with TCNQF4 2- generates a metal-organic framework that can accommodate the [Cp2Co]+ cation. All three compounds have been further characterized by FTIR and UV-vis spectroscopy, electrochemically and by elemental analysis with all data being consistent with the formulations of [Cp2Co]TCNQF4 (1 and 2) and [Cp2Co]Li(TCNQF4) (3). Compound 3, containing dianionic TCNQF4 2-, is stable in air.

A CH3CN (5 mL) solution of [Cp2Co]­PF6 (33.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added to a CH3OH (6 mL) solution of LiTCNQF4 (28.3 mg, 0.1 mmol). The resultant mixture was stirred for 1 h under N2 and filtered to remove the precipitate. The filtrate was diffused with diethyl ether, yielding purple-blue single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis (38 mg, 82%, based on LiTCNQF4). FTIR (ν/cm–1): 3103 (w), 2191 (s), 2179 (s), 2166 (m), 1632 (m), 1535 (m), 1496 (m), 1414 (w), 1382 (s), 1347 (m), 1336 (m), 1261 (w), 1197 (m), 1139 (m), 1010 (w), 966 (s), 871 (m), 786 (m), 715 (w). UV–vis (CH3CN): λmax; 262, 412, 753 (nm). Elemental analysis: for [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4, C22H10N4F4Co, 465.27, Calcd (%): C: 56.79%, H: 2.17%, N: 12.04%. Found: C: 56.63%, H: 2.26%; N: 12.18%.

Synthesis of <bold>2</bold>, [Cp<sub>2</sub>Co]­TCNQF<sub>4</sub>, Polymorph β

In an endeavor to rationally prepare [Cp2Co]+ materials that contain TCNQF4 0 < n <1–, the synthesis of 1 was repeated in the presence of 2.5%, 5%, and 10% neutral TCNQF4. While this did not lead to isolation of fractionally reduced materials, intriguingly, only a semiconducting polymorph β (2) was obtained, rather than polymorph α (1) or a mixture of polymorphs. The yield of polymorph β (2) increased in proportion to the percentage TCNQF4 present. Thus, in the highest yielding synthesis, a CH3CN solution of [Cp2Co]­PF6 (33.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was added to a CH3OH solution of LiTCNQF4 (28.3 mg, 0.1 mmol) containing 10% TCNQF4 (2.76 mg, 0.01 mmol). The resultant mixture was stirred for 1 h under N2 and filtered to remove the precipitate. The filtrate was diffused with diethyl ether, yielding blue, single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis (28 mg, 82%, based on LiTCNQF4). FTIR (ν/cm–1): 3105 (w), 2193 (s), 2176 (s), 2168 (m), 1634 (m), 1592 (m), 1538 (m), 1498 (m), 1488­(m), 1414 (w), 1383 (s), 1347 (m), 1337 (m), 1264 (w), 1241 (w), 1200 (m), 1142 (m), 1065 (w), 1013 (w), 969 (s), 873 (m), 860 (m), 805 (w), 788 (w), 716­(w). UV–vis (CH3CN): λmax; 262, 412, 753 (nm). Elemental analysis: for [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4, C22H10N4F4Co, 465.27, Calcd (%): C: 56.79%, H: 2.17%, N: 12.04%. Found: C: 56.57%, H: 2.31%; N: 12.20%.

A rationalization of the role of neutral TCNQ in the synthesis of polymorph β (2) is given in the .

Synthesis of <bold>3</bold>, [Cp<sub>2</sub>Co]­Li­(TCNQF<sub>4</sub>)

Li2TCNQF4 (29 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of CH3OH and mixed with a solution of [Cp2Co]­PF6 (33.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) in CH3CN (5 mL). The resulting solution was stirred for 1 h under N2 and diffused with diethyl ether to produce dark orange-colored single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis (35 mg, 74%, based on Li2TCNQF4). FTIR (ν/cm–1): 3119 (w), 2202 (w), 2176 (s), 2151 (s), 2134 (s), 2106 (m), 1489 (s), 1478 (s), 1414 (s), 1312 (w), 1227 (s), 1148 (m), 1009 (m), 959 (s), 860 (s), 788 (s). UV–vis (CH3CN): λmax; 218, 262, 333 (nm). Elemental analysis: for [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4), C22H10N4F4CoLi, 472.21, Calculated (%): C: 55.96%, H: 2.13%, N: 11.86%. Found: C: 55.83%, H: 2.42%; N:11.86%.

cln_elements.content:
The cyclic voltammogram obtained at a scan rate of 200 mVs–1 for 0.38 mM of (3), [Cp2Co]­Li­(TCNQF4) in CH3CN (0.1 M Bu4NPF6) shown in a, displays two reversible, diffusion-controlled, one-electron oxidation processes and a reversible reduction process. These processes correspond to sequential oxidation of TCNQF4 2– to TCNQF4 1– () and then to TCNQF4 0 () and reduction of [Cp2Co]+ to [Cp2Co]0 (). The midpoint potentials are E m1 = −0.33 mV, E m2 = 0.19 mV, and E m3 = −1.33 mV (vs Fc0/+), where E m is the average of the reduction (E p red) and oxidation (E p ox) peak potentials and represents a close approximation of the reversible formal potential E 0 f. The separation in the potentials for the two TCNQF4-based oxidation processes is 0.52 V and is consistent with literature data reported under similar conditions. A scan rate study for the oxidation step over the range of 50–1000 mV s–1 is shown in Figure S6b in Supporting Information. These voltammetric data imply that upon dissolution of (3) in CH3CN, TCNQF4 2– and [Cp2Co]+ are formed with both species being stable on the time-scale of these studies.

The voltammetric behavior of the two polymorphs of [Cp2Co]­TCNQF4, dissolved in acetonitrile solution, is identical. A transient cyclic voltammogram obtained at a scan rate of 100 mV s–1 for 1.0 mM of (1) in CH3CN (0.1 M Bu4NPF6) is shown in a and displays two TCNQF4-based diffusion-controlled, electrochemically and chemically reversible processes. The scan rate dependence of (1) is shown in Figure S6­(a) of the Supporting Information. In this case, the first TCNQF4-based process is for reduction of TCNQF4 1– to TCNQF4 2– () followed by the process for oxidation of TCNQF4 1– to TCNQF4 0 (). The midpoint potentials are E m1 = −0.36 V and E m2 = 0.18 V (vs Fc0/+). The separation in the potentials for the two processes is again 0.52 V and consistent with the literature. A reversible [Cp2Co]+/0 reduction process is also detected (data not shown) and is derived from the reaction in . These voltammetric data imply that upon dissolution of 1 in CH3CN, TCNQF4 1– and [Cp2Co]+ are formed.

Electronic (UV–vis) Spectroscopy

UV–vis spectra of 1, 2, 3, and [Cp2Co]­PF6 dissolved in CH3CN are shown in . Both (1 and 2) exhibit absorption bands with λmax values of 261, 412, and 754 nm, which are characteristic of the TCNQF4 1– radical anion. In the case of 3, the spectrum is dominated by three intense absorption bands with λmax at 219, 333, and 261 nm which are assigned to the TCNQF4 2– dianion and the [Cp2Co]+ cation. These results are consistent with previous reports and confirm the conclusions reached from structural, vibrational, and electrochemical studies.
